Introduction

Dermatologic terminology is essential for accurate communication and clinical reasoning.  Dermatologic descriptions typically incorporate the following elements:



  • Primary morphology (eg, macule, papule).
  • Size.
  • Demarcation (eg, well demarcated, poorly demarcated).
  • Color.
  • Secondary morphology (eg, erosion, ulceration).
  • Distribution (eg, photodistributive, generalized).


This article provides an overview of skin anatomy and the terminology used to describe skin rashes and cutaneous findings.

Structures of the skin



The skin consists of 3 primary layers (

figure 1
): epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue.

Epidermis



The outermost layer, the epidermis, is composed primarily of keratinocytes (

figure 2
).  It includes (from deep to superficial):



  • Stratum basale:  Composed of a single layer of basal keratinocytes undergoing mitosis, melanocytes (which give skin its color), and Merkel cells (mechanoreceptors involved in the sensation of touch) (
    figure 3
    ).
  • Stratum spinosum:  Composed of a thick layer of living skin cells connected by desmosomes, which provide mechanical strength (and give the cells a spiny appearance under the microscope).  Langerhans cells (antigen-presenting immune cells) are abundant in this layer.
  • Stratum granulosum:  Contains keratohyalin granules rich in profilaggrin and loricrin, which contribute to keratinocyte maturation and skin barrier integrity.  Lamellar bodies release lipids that form a waterproof barrier.
  • Stratum corneum:  Composed of anucleate, flattened keratinocytes embedded in a lipid matrix, forming a protective, hydrophobic barrier that prevents water loss and pathogen entry.


Thick skin (eg, palms, soles) has an additional layer, the stratum lucidum, between the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum layers.

Dermis



The dermis is the connective tissue layer below the epidermis and consists of 2 layers:



  • Reticular dermis (deep layer):  Composed of a thick layer of dense, irregular connective tissue; rich in type I collagen and thick elastin fibers that provide structural integrity and resistance to mechanical forces.  This layer also contains larger blood vessels, lymphatic vessels, cutaneous nerves, and adnexal structures (eg, hair follicles, sebaceous glands, sweat glands).
  • Papillary dermis (superficial layer):  Consists of loose connective tissue rich in elastin fibers and types I and III collagen, which provide tensile strength and elasticity.  It also contains dermal papillae, capillary loops, and sensory nerve endings (eg, Meissner corpuscles) responsible for detecting light touch.


The dermis plays an important role in thermoregulation (blood vessels regulate heat through vasodilation/constriction, sweat glands aid cooling), immune defense (houses dendritic cells, mast cells, lymphocytes), and wound healing (fibroblasts produce collagen).



Subcutaneous tissue (hypodermis)



Located beneath the dermis, the subcutaneous tissue is the deepest layer of the skin and consists primarily of adipose tissue interspersed with connective tissue septa, blood vessels, and lymphatics.  It has the following functions:



  • Insulation.
  • Energy storage in the form of fat.
  • Shock absorption:  Cushions underlying muscles, bones, and organs from mechanical trauma.
  • Structural support:  Anchors the skin to deeper tissues while allowing for mobility.


This tissue is highly vascularized, housing larger blood vessels that supply the dermis and epidermis.  Nerve endings (eg, Pacinian corpuscles) in this layer contribute to the sensations of deep pressure and vibration.

Terminology for dermatologic lesions

Primary lesions



Primary lesions arise de novo, reflecting the initial pathogenic changes of a dermatologic disease process, and include:



  • Macule:  A flat, nonpalpable area of color change <1 cm (eg, freckles, lentigines).
  • Patch:  A macule >1 cm (eg, vitiligo, caf√© au lait spots) (
    image 1
    ).
  • Papule:  A raised, solid lesion <1 cm (eg, lichen planus, acne, molluscum contagiosum) (
    image 2
    ).
  • Plaque:  A raised lesion >1 cm, often with scaling (eg, psoriasis, lichen simplex chronicus) (
    image 3
    ).
  • Nodule:  A deeper, solid lesion >1 cm, often involving the dermis or subcutaneous tissue (eg, dermatofibroma, lipoma) (
    image 4
    ).
  • Vesicle:  A small, fluid-filled blister <1 cm (eg, herpes simplex, varicella) (
    image 5
    ).
  • Bulla:  A large, fluid-filled blister >1 cm (eg, bullous pemphigoid, second-degree burn) (
    image 6
    ).
  • Pustule:  A pus-filled vesicle or papule (eg, folliculitis, pustular psoriasis) (
    image 7
    ).
  • Wheal:  A transient, edematous raised plaque resulting from dermal edema (eg, urticaria) (
    image 8
    ).


These descriptive terms can be used together.  For example, a maculopapular rash contains both macular (flat) and papular (raised) components.  The underlying cause could be a viral exanthem, a bacterial infection, a drug reaction, or an inflammatory condition.

Secondary lesions



Secondary lesions result from evolution of primary lesions, trauma, or external factors and include:



  • Scale:  Excessive accumulation of stratum corneum that presents as flakes or plates on the skin's surface due to abnormal keratinization or shedding.  It is commonly seen in psoriasis, ichthyosis, and seborrheic dermatitis (
    image 9
    ).
  • Crust:  Accumulation of dried exudate (composed of serum, blood, or pus) on the skin surface following the rupture of vesicles, pustules, or erosions.  This lesion is commonly seen in impetigo or healing wounds (
    image 10
    ).
  • Erosion:  Superficial loss of the epidermis that does not penetrate the dermis, typically resulting from trauma, inflammation, or rupture of vesicles or bullae.  It heals without scarring because it does not extend beyond the basal layer of the epidermis (
    image 11
    ).
  • Ulcer:  Full-thickness epidermal loss extending into the dermis or beyond, often leading to scarring (eg, venous stasis ulcers, pressure ulcers) (
    image 12
    ).
  • Fissure:  Linear split extending into the dermis.  It is commonly seen in chronic dermatitis of the hand and tinea pedis (
    image 13
    ).
  • Atrophy:  Pathologic thinning of the epidermis, dermis, or subcutaneous tissue, resulting in a fragile, translucent appearance with increased susceptibility to injury.  Atrophy occurs for different reasons; chronic daily use of topical corticosteroids can cause cutaneous atrophy due to the inhibition of epidermal keratinocyte proliferation and fibroblast function.  Atrophy can also be pressure-induced and is common in aging skin (
    image 14
    ).
  • Lichenification:  Thickening of the skin with accentuated skin markings due to chronic rubbing or scratching.  This lesion occurs in atopic dermatitis (
    image 15
    ).


Primary lesions typically provide the initial clues to a diagnosis, whereas secondary changes offer insight into disease progression and external influences (eg, trauma, environmental factors).

Clinical correlations



The following clinical correlations highlight important dermatologic findings and their associated diseases.



  • Annular lesion:  A ring-shaped skin abnormality with a clear center and an advancing erythematous or scaly border; commonly associated with dermatologic conditions such as tinea corporis, erythema annulare centrifugum, or granuloma annulare (
    image 16
    ).
  • Target lesion:  A concentric skin abnormality with a dusky center (often with a small bulla or crust), a pale surrounding zone, and an erythematous peripheral border; commonly seen in erythema multiforme and drug reactions (
    image 17
    ).
  • Koebner phenomenon:  A pathophysiologic reaction in which new lesions of a preexisting dermatosis (eg, psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo) develop at sites of trauma (
    image 18
    ).  The exact mechanism of this response is unclear but likely involves immune dysregulation and epidermal turnover abnormalities.
  • Auspitz sign:  Pinpoint bleeding upon removal of psoriatic scales due to dilated underlying capillaries (
    image 19
    ).
  • Nikolsky sign:  Dermatologic sign characterized by superficial epidermal detachment that occurs with slight mechanical pressure (eg, lateral traction or rubbing of intact skin).  It results from the loss of desmosomal integrity and can be mediated by autoantibody targeting of cadherins (eg, in pemphigus vulgaris) or widespread keratinocyte necrosis (eg, in toxic epidermal necrolysis).
  • Darier sign:  A dermatologic response where gentle rubbing or scratching of a lesion induces localized erythema, swelling, or urtication due to mast cell degranulation and histamine release.  It is a characteristic diagnostic feature of mastocytosis (
    image 20
    ).

Summary



Dermatologic terminology classifies skin findings based on structure, primary and secondary lesion types, and characteristic clinical patterns.  Precision of dermatologic description is essential for effective diagnosis, treatment, and communication in clinical practice.
